::: columns ::: {.column width="25%"} {{< li gaqzgxto trigger=loop delay=1000 colors=secondary:#e76254 class=large >}} ::: ::: {.column width="75%"} - Which trend can you identify for the wage share in most European countries and why is that? - What are Kuznets Waves? - What does the elephant curve by Branko Milanovic show? - What are malign and benign factors that might lead to a decrease in global inequality? ::: ::: # What is wealth and how do we measure it? ::: {.absolute top="90%" left="30%" width="369" height="400"} ![](../../data/img/avatar_leger.png) ::: ::: footer ::: ## Definition of private wealth {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {style="font-size:1.5rem"} ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Non-financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Dwellings (owner-occupied residence, other real estate) - Consumer durables (vehicles, etc.) - Valuables - Intellectual property ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Currency and deposits - Net equity in own unincorporated business - Mututal funds and investment funds - (Private) Pensions funds - Bonds and other debt securities - Shares and other equity - Life insurance funds -Other financial assets ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Liabilities**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Owner-occupied residence loans - Consumer durable loans (e.g. for vehicles) - Other investment loans (collateralized) - Other loans (e.g. education loans) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.absolute top="70%" left="60%" .textbox .fragment .fade-up} No human, social and cultural capital; No public social security pensions (marketable vs. augmented wealth) ::: ::: {.aside} Source: @oecd:2013 ::: ## HFCS versus National Accounts {.smaller} ::: {.tbl-classic .tbl-larger} | Underreporting in HFCS in % of NA | Tangible assets | Financial wealth | Liabilities | Net wealth | |-----|:-----:|:-----:|:-----:|:-----:| Austria | -8 | 62 | 59 | 12 | Germany | 15 | 58 | 29 | 30 | France | 17 | 61 | 33 | 32 | Spain | 16 | 63 | 39 | 24 | Italy | -5 | 80 | 60 | 23 | Belgium | -21 | 42 | 24 | 6 | Finland | -1 | 63 | 12 | 22 | Netherlands | 13 | 86 | 16 | 47 | : {tbl-colwidths="[20,15,15,15,15]"} ::: ::: {.aside} Source: @vermeulen:2016 ::: ## Why is there underreporting in HFCS? ::: {.incremental style="font-size:1.8rem"} - Target population in Austria: [3.9 million households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Gross sample in HFCS 2017: [6,280 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Realized interviews: [3,072 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Response rate in HFCS 2017: [approx. 50%]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Residual: [refused interviews]{.marker-hl}, invalid addresses, households not available, etc. ::: ::: {.absolute bottom="5%" left="10%" width="800px" .textbox .fragment .fade-up style="font-size:1.7rem;padding:0.5rem 1rem;" .altlist} - Response refusal correlates with wealth and is highest at the top [@vermeulen:2016] - Wealthy households own a greater number of assets and miss some components more easily [@kennickell:1999] ::: ::: {.notes} Press R ::: # How to deal with the missing top in wealth surveys? ::: {.absolute top="90%" left="30%" width="369" height="400"} ![](../../data/img/avatar_hands.png) ::: ::: footer ::: ## Upstream strategy: Oversampling {.smaller} - Undercoverage and Underreporting - Oversampling is crucial for wealth surveys - Oversampling in HFCS 2017: :belgium: :cyprus: :de: :estonia: :es: :finland: :fr: :greece: :croatia: :hungary: :ireland: :latvia: :lithuania: :luxembourg: :poland: :portugal: :slovakia: - No oversampling: :austria: :it: :malta: :netherlands: :slovenia: - How does oversampling work? - External personal wealth data (:fr: :es:) - List of streets with high-income people (:de: :slovakia:) - Income tax data (:luxembourg: 20% of the sample from top 10% earners) - Regions with higher average income (:poland:) ## Downstream strategy: Pareto estimation {.smaller} - Pareto-Distribution is a sensible approximation to the distribution of large wealth - Two parameters: - Threshold for "large" wealth $m$ - Pareto-Index $\alpha$ $$P_i(x_i) = Pr(X_i \leqslant x_i) = 1 - \left(\frac{m_i}{x_i}\right)^{\alpha_i}$$ $$\forall ~\text{implicates} ~i = 1...5 \wedge x_i \geqslant m_i$$ ::: {.fragment .fade-in} [A smaller $\alpha$ means greater inequality. Empirically, $\alpha$ often is around 1.5 for wealth.]{.bubble .bubble-bottom-left .absolute top="27%" right="0%" style="--bubcol: var(--bubcol-red);max-width:400px;font-size:1.4rem;"} ::: ::: {.aside} Reading recommendation: @gabaix:2016 ::: ## European Rich List Database (ERLDB) and HFCS ![](img/rlmap_col.png){fig-align="center"} ## Cumulative density function of wealth in Germany ![](img/ccdf_col.png){fig-align="center"} ## Adjustment of top 1% shares ![](img/topshares_col.png){fig-align="center"} ## Convergence of adjusted survey data and national accounts ![](img/na_col.png){fig-align="center"} # Wealth distribution in Austria ::: {.absolute top="90%" left="30%" width="369" height="400"} ![](../../data/img/avatar_laptop.png) ::: ::: footer ::: ## Self-positioning in the wealth distribution {.smaller} ```{r packages} #| echo: false #| warning: false librarian::shelf(tidyverse, knitr, kableExtra, msthemes, MetBrewer, colorspace) options(knitr.kable.NA = '') ``` ```{r selfass} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' #| fig-align: "center" #| fig-height: 3.5 load("data/selfassessment.RData") selfassessment |> ggplot(aes(x=aha0500, y=perc)) + geom_hline(yintercept=10, color="#d03161") + geom_bar(stat="identity", fill="#5d8198") + scale_x_continuous(breaks=1:10) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale=1)) + labs(x="Net wealth deciles", y=NULL) + theme_ms() + theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), axis.text.x = element_text(size=12)) ``` . . . ::: {.altlist style="font-size:1.3rem;text-align:center"} - Correct positioning of households in the richest decile: [0]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Average estimated decile in the richest decile: [6]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Average estimated decile in the poorest decile: [3]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} ::: ::: {.aside} For animated version, see [here](https://twitter.com/matschnetzer/status/1091679602265780225) ::: ## Net wealth distribution in Austria {.smaller} ```{r ineq} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' wineq <- tribble( ~group, ~share, ~popshare, "Top 1%", 38.9, 1, "Top 2-5%", 16.2, 4, "Top 6-10%", 10.6, 5, "Top 11-50%", 31.4, 40, "Bottom 50%", 2.8, 50 ) |> mutate(group = factor(group, levels = rev(group)), labpos = cumsum(share)- 0.5*share) wineq |> ggplot(aes(x="", y=share, fill=group)) + geom_bar(stat="identity", width=1) + coord_polar("y", start=0) + labs(x=NULL, y=NULL) + geom_label(aes(x = 1.5, y = labpos, label = glue::glue("{group} \n own {share}%")), color = "white", size=4, family="Raleway", fontface="bold") + scale_fill_manual(values=met.brewer("Juarez")) + theme_ms(grid = F) + theme(axis.text = element_blank(), legend.position="none") ``` . . . [Median: 83,000€]{.bubble .bubble-bottom-left .absolute top="17%" right="0%" style="--bubcol: var(--bubcol-blue);font-size:1.2rem;"} . . . [Average net wealth
of total population:
318,000€]{.bubble .bubble-bottom-right .absolute top="35%" right="0%" style="--bubcol: var(--bubcol-dred);font-size:1.2rem;"} . . . [Average net wealth
of top 1%:
12,500,000€]{.bubble .bubble-bottom-left .absolute top="60%" right="0%" style="--bubcol: var(--bubcol-blue);font-size:1.2rem;"} ::: {.aside} Source: @heck:2020 ::: ## Alternative figure for wealth distribution ```{r waffle} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' library(waffle) wineq |> select(group, `Wealth share`=share, `Population share`=popshare) |> pivot_longer(cols = -group, names_to = "cat", values_to = "value") |> mutate(value = round(value,0)) |> ggplot(aes(fill=group, values=value)) + geom_waffle(color = "white", size=1.125, n_rows = 5) + facet_wrap(~cat, ncol=1) + scale_x_discrete(expand=c(0,0)) + scale_y_discrete(expand=c(0,0)) + scale_fill_manual(values = met.brewer("Juarez"), guide = guide_legend(reverse=T, keywidth = 0.5, keyheight = 2)) + theme_ms(grid=F,alttf=T) + theme(strip.text.x = element_text(size=20,margin=margin(b=5, t=5)), legend.text = element_text(size=14), legend.title=element_blank()) + coord_equal() + theme_enhance_waffle() ``` ## Participation in wealth components ```{r participation} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' load("data/participation.RData") participation |> rename(Vehicles = cars, `Owner-occupied residence` = mainres, `Other real estate` = othres, `Business wealth` = business, Deposits = sightacc, `Saving accounts` = savacc, `Mutual and investment funds` = funds, Bonds = bonds, Shares = shares) |> pivot_longer(-group) |> pivot_wider(names_from=group) |> rename(`Participation in %` = name, `Bottom half
(0-50%)` = low50, `Upper middle
(51-80%)` = `50to80`, `Affluent
(91-95%)` = `80to95`, `Top 5%
(96-100%)` = rich) |> kbl(escape = FALSE, align = "lcccc", digits=1) |> kable_classic(full_width = FALSE) |> column_spec(1, width = "15%") |> column_spec(2:5, width = "10%") |> row_spec(4, extra_css="border-bottom:3px solid;") ``` ## Gender net wealth gap in Austria { .smaller } ::: {.tbl-classic .tbl-smaller} | | Mean wealth | Mean GWG (in €) | Mean GWG (in %) | Median Wealth | Median GWG (in €) | Median GWG (in %) | |-|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:| | *All respondents* | | Couples | 356,553 | | | 173,683 | | | Male | 207,485 | 58,417 | 28 | 82,285 | 13,862 | 17 | | Female | 149,068 | | | 68,422 | | | | *Male respondent* | | Male | 270,307 | 110,995 | 41.1 | 99,347 | 27,085 | 27.3 | | Female | 159,312 | | | 72,262 | | | *Female respondent* | | Male | 138,830 | 957 | 0.7 | 63,825 | −1,395 | -2.2 | | Female | 137,873 | | | 65,220 | | : {tbl-colwidths="[20,13,13,13,13,13,13]"} ::: ::: {.aside} Note: The respondent in HFCS is the [financially most knowledgeable person]{.marker-hl} who is best informed about the household's finances.
Source: @rehm:2022 ::: ## Migrant net wealth gap in Austria {.smaller} ::: {.tbl-classic .tbl-smaller} | | Mean wealth | Mean MWG (in €) | Mean MWG (in %) | Median Wealth | Median MWG (in €) | Median MWG (in %) | |-|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:| | Natives | 165,730 | | | 59,001 | | | *Migrants* | | Total | 98,007 | 67,723 | 41 | 15,931 | 43,070 | 73 | | 1st generation | 63,001 | 102,729 | 62 | 9,917 | 49,084 | 83 | | 2nd generation | 139,775 | 25,955 | 16 | 32,763 | 26,238 | 44 | | *1st generation migrants only* | | Short stay | 39,598 | 126,132 | 76 | 4,935 | 54,066 | 92 | | Long stay | 86,317 | 79,413 | 48 | 20,196 | 38,805 | 66 | : {tbl-colwidths="[20,13,13,13,13,13,13]"} ::: ::: {.aside} Note: First-generation migrants are distinguished into short (⩽20 years) and long (>20 years) time since arrival in Austria.
Source: @muckenhuber:2022 ::: # Global wealth distribution ::: {.absolute top="90%" left="30%" width="369" height="400"} ![](../../data/img/avatar_point.png) ::: ::: footer ::: ## Global income and wealth inequality {.smaller} ![](img/incwealthineq.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: ## Income and wealth inequality across Europe ```{r ginis} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' load("data/ginidat.RData") ginidat |> ggplot(aes(x=reorder(geo, rank, na.rm=T))) + geom_segment(aes(y = 0, yend = values, xend=geo), size = 0.1, color="grey70") + geom_point(aes(y=values, group = type, shape = type, color = type), size = 3) + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = mean(values[type=="Income"])), size = 0.1, linetype = "longdash") + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = mean(values[type=="Wealth"], na.rm=T)), size = 0.1, linetype = "longdash") + annotate("text", x = 24, y = 68, label = "Average", size = 3) + scale_color_manual(values = met.brewer("Juarez"), labels = c("Income" = "Disposable income (Eurostat)", "Wealth" = "Net wealth (HFCS)")) + scale_shape_manual(values = c(19,17), labels = c("Income" = "Disposable income (Eurostat)", "Wealth" = "Net wealth (HFCS)")) + theme_ms() + labs(x="",y="Gini index") + theme(legend.title = element_blank(), legend.text = element_text(size=14), axis.title = element_text(size = 14), axis.text = element_text(size = 12), legend.position = "bottom", axis.title.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()) ``` ## Extreme global wealth inequality {.smaller} ![](img/extremeineq.png){fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: ## Private and public wealth {.smaller} ![](img/privpubwealth.png){fig-align="center" height="500px"} ::: {.aside} Source: @wir:2022 ::: ## Bibliography {.bibstyle} :::footer :::
